[SYNTAX]: Severely garbled sentence ("As loomed this up wondered I...") disrupting readability.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift between anecdotes (e.g., dinner story to colonial example) without clear connectors.

[SYNTAX]: Completely incoherent sentence structure ("The and enter sects...") disrupting flow.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between paragraphs (e.g., shifting from literary criticism to personal book collections).

[SYNTAX]: Severely jumbled sentence structure ("He for whose now this Bill...") causing confusion.
[GRAMMAR]: Minor archaic phrasing (e.g., "before me") that slightly strains modern readability.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between book references (e.g., Red Indian stories to Scott/Thackeray).
[STRUCTURE]: Tangential analogy ("Mohammedan converted...") disrupting thematic flow.

[SYNTAX]: "And her beaten, surely Esmond is again thinks, as gold this of." (incoherent sentence structure)

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt thematic shifts (e.g., from heroine comparison to book arrangement without clear connectors)

[COMPLEXITY]: Overly complex sentence structures with multiple embedded clauses.
[TRANSITION]: Abrupt integration of quoted material without clear lead-in.

[STRUCTURE]: Loose thematic connections between paragraphs (e.g., Mary Queen of Scots to hereditary book mania).
[CLARITY]: Unresolved typographical/error in mid-text ("A might instance...").
[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from anecdotal examples to allegorical pledge scenario.

[SYNTAX]: Multiple sentences with disjointed word order (e.g., "He things restored is not a vain legacies come be...").
[GRAMMAR]: Frequent grammatical errors (e.g., "One been he has, at rascal so to him...").
[LEXICON]: Awkward phrasing (e.g., "the book he purchases with the complete priceâ€”that is the price to which he has brought down the seller...").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between ideas (e.g., shift from conscience to birthday scenario).
[CLARITY]: Incomprehensible segments disrupting narrative flow (e.g., "He things restored...").
[TRANSITION]: Lack of logical connections between paragraphs (e.g., jump from literary figures to Emerson quote).
